p.s: Sing, goddess, the immortal wrath of Achilles, son of Peleus, that cursed wrath that caused countless pains for the Achaeans and hurled to Hades many brave souls of warriors, and made their bodies into scraps for the dogs and for all the birds,

and the plan of Zeus was being performed, from the point where first they stood apart, quarreling, the son of Atreus, lord of men, and god-like Achilles.
Who of the gods brought the two together to fight in strife?
The son of Leto and Zeus:
for he, enraged by the king, sent a wicked plague up through the camp,
and the army was dying, because he dishonored that priest, Chryses, he, the son of Atreus:
for he went towards the swift ships of the Achaeans in order to free his daughter, bearing boundless ransom, holding the wreaths of the free-shooter Apollo in his hands and up along his golden scepter,
and he was begging all the Achaeans, but especially the two sons of Atreus, the commanders of the host:
“Both the sons of Atreus and all the well-greaved Achaeans, while I wish that the gods, holding Olympian homes, grant for you to sack utterly the city of Priam, and to return safely home;
but free my beloved child to me, and accept this ransom, reverencing the son of Zeus, the free-shooter Apollo.”
Then, on one hand, all the Achaeans shouted their assent both to praisecheck transation the priest and to accept the shining ransom;

When they had been assembled and were they gathered together, swift-footed Achilles rose up and spoke among them:
“Son of Atreus, now I believe that we, driven back from the city will go to back to our homes again, if death, in fact, we may flee, if indeedthese double "if" clauses do different things -- I don't know how best to capture their force. war and plague together are going to overcome the Achaeans:
But come, we will ask either some seer or priest or even a dream-interpreter, for even a dream is from Zeus. For he may say why Phoebus Apollo was angered so greatly, whether the free-shooter reproaches us on account of a vow or an offering, or if somehow having encountered the rich aroma from unblemished sheep or goats he is willing to avert ruin from us.”
And, speaking thus, he was seating himself down:
Among them rose Calchas son of Thestor, best by far of all the prophets, who knows what is and what shall be and what was before, and who had lead the ships of the Achaeans into Troy through his own gift of prophecy, which Phoebus Apollo gave to him:
He, well-disposed, began speaking in the assembly and addressed them: “Oh Achilles, beloved of Zeus, you urge me to tell the wrath of Apollo, the lord sharp-shooter: therefore I will speak: but you put together and swear to me that you will gladly assist me with words and with hands. For indeed I believe that I will anger a man, he who greatly rules over all the Argives, and the Achaeans are influenced by him: for the king is mightier, whenever he is angry at an inferior man. For even if he will repress the anger the same day, but afterwards he holds the grudge, until he can fulfill it, in his breast: but you consider if you will protect me.” And swift-footed Achilles, answering him, was speaking: “Being of exceedingly good courage, speak the prophecy which you know: for I pledge by Apollo, beloved of Zeus, and to whom you, Calchas, are praying, you reveal the prophecies to the Danaans, no one with me living and beholding on this earth will bear heavy hands against you near the hollow ships of the all the Danaans together, not even if you say Agamemnon, he who boasts much to be the best of the Achaeans.” And then the blameless seer took courage and spoke: “Indeed he finds blame neither by vow nor by offering, but on behalf of the priest, whom Agamemnon dishonored when he did not free the daughter and he did not receive the ransom, indeed on account of this the free-shooter gave sorrows and will continue to give still. And not sooner will he drive off shameful destruction for the Danaans, until we give back the bright-eyed maiden to her beloved father without a price, un-ransomed, and to lead a holy offering into Chrysa: then we, appeasing him, may persuade him.”
